prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Investigating the disks around Herbig Be stars - 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Here we probe 12CO , 13CO and C18O that are simultaneously observable in a Band 6 spectral setup. We use these and the continuum as the primary tracers of the disks around a sample of Herbig Be sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We have set the correlator such that we can simultaneously target 12CO 13CO and C18O. When considering our science goal and time requirements a 0.6 km/s channel is suitable. Where possible we have spectrally averaged the channels to keep the data rate lower. We discuss the setup per baseband below:
BB1 - We center on H2CO at 218.47 GHz with a 937.5 MHz bandwidth and 0.66 km/s spectral resolution in FDM mode. This band also covers another H2CO line and the OCS line (c.f. Survey of molecular lines in Orion - Sutton et al. 1985) but is relatively line free. We chose H2CO as the have been seen particularly in more high mass environments and may provide a further link between Herbig Be and MYSOs, as discuss ing the proposal (see also. Jimenez-serra et al. 2012). Using the FDM mode we can possibly detect these lines, but mainly use the line free channels such that we improve the continuum bandwidth.
BB2 - We have 4 windows here, 2 targetting 13CO, C18O our key tracers. Given the corrlator flexibility we can also target the strong lines SO and HNCO (Sutton et al. 1985). The lines have already been observed in disks in low mass protostars and in the environment of high mass protostars.
BB3 - This is setup to target our final key tracer 12CO. Furthermore, given the correlator flexibility we also target OCS another strong line in the Orion survey by Sutton et al. (1985). We also spectrally average to keep data rates low.
BB4 - This is a pure continuum window with 1875 Mhz bandwidth in FDM mode. We pick a line free region using Sutton et al. (1985) however are aware of potential contamination and hence choose for FDM rather than TDM such that we can remove any contaminating lines from the continuum.

The smallest angular scale is selected such that we probe 100 au physical scales for our most distance source of the entire sample. This still allows us the resolve disks with expected radii of 200-300 au and such that we probe similar scales as observations of low-mass protostellar disks such that we can undertake a like-for-like comparison.
From the scale of the disks we do not expect the size to exceed the physical scales we probe. For the closest source (~300 pc) we may resolve out the very largest scales if the disk extends much over 600 AU in physical size however this would be a particularly large disk.

These observations are to catagorise the disk using dust continuum and molecular line observations of CO. The entire driver of the sensitivity is based upon detection of the weakest isotopologue C18O in a 0.6 km/s channel. Note this channel width is adequate to resolve the velocity structure of the disk over ~9-10 spectral elements.
As there are no prior observations of these targets we scale previous observations to check the expected flux from the same physical region of the disk AND also produce a model using Pro-DiMo (figure 2 in the proposal) to predict the flux from a fiducial 300 au radius disk, 0.2 Mo in mass, around a 5 Mo star located at a distance of 400 pc.
The following are our workings: SCALING Based on HD142527 - Distance = 140 pc The peak C18O(2-1) flux is 0.39 Jy/beam/chan (beam = 0.85 x 0.64 arcsec) Scale to median distance of our sample (470 pc) -> divide by ~3.36 Now expected flux is 0.12 Jy/beam/chan (0.85 x 0.64 arcsec beam)
Physical area of the disk probed for HD142527 (in AU) is: = (0.85x140)x(0.64x140) = 10662 AU^2
Physical area of our Herbig Be disk at 470 pc with a 0.13 beam is: = (0.13x470)x(0.13X470) = 3733 AU^2
So with our 0.13 arcsec beam we probe a physical area 2.85 times smaller. Divide by this area ratio: 0.12/2.85 = 0.042 Jy/beam/chan (0.13x0.13 beam)
Thus from such a scaling we expect a peak of 42 mJy/beam/channel. NOTE, if we repeat this for a larger distance the expected peak flux actually increases (to 50 mJy/beam/chan) as a larger fraction of the disk is observed in one beam.
MODEL: In figure 2 we show the line profile expected from the disk. This is for an aperture of 0.75 arcsec in radius to cover the disk which is 300 au in radius and at a distance of 400 pc. The peak flux we find is 1.4 Jy in an area of PI x 0.75^2 = 1.767 arcsec^2 in a single channel (see profile of the emission in figure 2).
Assuming the worst case scenario of uniform emission, and using our 0.13''x0.13'' beam with area 0.0169 arcsec^2 we must scale down by a factor of 104.1
Therefore, 1.4 Jy (in a 0.75'' radius aperture) per channel / 104.1 = 0.0134 Jy/beam/chan (0.13 arcsec beam)
CONCLUSION: We find that the model produces the lower estimates of the peak C18O emission per channel. For a 5 sigma detection of the C18O based on the model, we require a sensitivity of 2.6 mJy/beam/channel (0.6 km/s channel)

Our data rate is 15.26 MB/s. We have already acted to spectrally average the data to reduce this. The main issue that increases the data rate is the 1875 MHz wide FDM window in BB4. However as we note above, we need this in FDM mode to remove any line contamination from the continuum, although we have attempted to select a line free emission range. This is impreative such that we can obtain accurate continuum fluxes.

BB1 - We center on H2CO at 218.47 GHz with a 937.5 MHz bandwidth and 0.66 km/s spectral resolution in FDM mode. This band also covers another H2CO line and the OCS line (c.f. Survey of molecular lines in Orion - Sutton et al. 1985) but is relatively line free. We chose H2CO as the have been seen particularly in more high mass environments and may provide a further link between Herbig Be and MYSOs, as discuss ing the proposal (see also. Jimenez-serra et al. 2012). Using the FDM mode we can possibly detect these lines, but mainly use the line free channels such that we improve the continuum bandwidth.

BB3 - This is setup to target our final key tracer 12CO. Furthermore, given the correlator flexibility we also target OCS another strong line in the Orion survey by Sutton et al. (1985). We also spectrally average to keep data rates low.
BB4 - This is a pure continuum window with 1875 Mhz bandwidth in FDM mode. We pick a line free region using Sutton et al. (1985) however are aware of potential contamination and hence choose for FDM rather than TDM such that we can remove any contaminating lines from the continuum.

These observations are to catagorise the disk using dust continuum and molecular line observations of CO. The following are our workings: SCALING Based on HD142527 - Distance = 140 pc The peak C18O(2-1) flux is 0.39 Jy/beam/chan (beam = 0.85 x 0.64 arcsec) Scale to median distance of our sample (470 pc) -> divide by ~3.36 Now expected flux is 0.12 Jy/beam/chan (0.85 x 0.64 arcsec beam)
Physical area of the disk probed for HD142527 (in AU) is: = (0.85x140)x(0.64x140) = 10662 AU^2
Physical area of our Herbig Be disk at 470 pc with a 0.13 beam is: = (0.13x470)x(0.13X470) = 3733 AU^2
So with our 0.13 arcsec beam we probe a physical area 2.85 times smaller. Divide by this area ratio: 0.12/2.85 = 0.042 Jy/beam/chan (0.13x0.13 beam)

The peak flux we find is 1.4 Jy in an area of PI x 0.75^2 = 1.767 arcsec^2 in a single channel (see profile of the emission in figure 2).
Assuming the worst case scenario of uniform emission, and using our 0.13''x0.13'' beam with area 0.0169 arcsec^2 we must scale down by a factor of 104.1
Therefore, 1.4 Jy (in a 0.75'' radius aperture) per channel / 104.1 = 0.0134 Jy/beam/chan (0.13 arcsec beam)

Our data rate is 15.26 MB/s. We have already acted to spectrally average the data to reduce this. The main issue that increases the data rate is the 1875 MHz wide FDM window in BB4. However as we note above, we need this in FDM mode to remove any line contamination from the continuum, although we have attempted to select a line free emission range. This is impreative such that we can obtain accurate continuum fluxes.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA observations of disks around intermediate mass Herbig Be stars, which bridge the mass range between T Tauri stars and Massive Young Stellar Objects. For the latter, the process by which they accrete material is not well characterised. The upper mass end of intermediate protostars, Herbig Be stars, may hold the key. The Herbig Be targets have been selected based on the presence of CO first overtone emission in their near-infrared (NIR) spectra, which has been shown to trace hot, small scale gaseous disks around such objects. Using the high spatial resolution available in Cycle 3, we will; (1) categorise the sub-mm component of these disks for the first time; and (2) compare and contrast disk properties with those obtained from our NIR spectroscopic study. These observations will provide the first high resolution (0.13'') sub-mm study of young stars in a poorly studied mass range (2.5-7.0 Mo), and will provide details on how massive star formation proceeds.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, St. Andrews, University of
